contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox chess player |name = Zoltán Almási |image = Almashi2007.jpg |birthname = Zoltán Almási |country = Hungary |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|8|29}} |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |title = [[Grandmaster (chess)|Grandmaster]] |worldchampion = |womensworldchampion = |rating = <br /><small>(No. 27 in the January 2012 [[FIDE World Rankings]])</small> |peakrating = 2726 (July 2011) |FideID = 702293 }} {{eastern name order|Almási Zoltán}} '''Zoltán Almási''' (born August 29, 1976) is a Hungarian [[chess]] [[Grandmaster (chess)|grandmaster]]. He is a seven-time [[Hungarian Chess Championship|Hungarian Chess Champion]], winning in 1995, 1997, 1999, 2000, 2003, 2006 and 2008. In the [[FIDE World Chess Championship 2004]], he made it to the fourth round where he lost 2–0 to [[Rustam Kasimdzhanov]], the eventual winner of the event. In 2008 he won the [[Reggio Emilia chess tournament|Reggio Emilia tournament]] in Italy scoring 5½/8.
